Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 04:56PM momof2greatkids wrote: DONE! Last rad today! So happy - exhausted, but happy! Had a great rad team, so grateful for them. Haven't missed much work since dx aug '10, and am just now ready to collapse. (chemo aug-dec, dec bmx, jan to now rads, herceptin continues for a year.) If I could just sleep I think I would for a week! God Bless all of you!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 08:50PM momof2greatkids wrote: Eloise and Saturn - Peninsula my old stomping grounds! It is so beautiful there, I miss it! I finished rad #19 (of 28+boosts). I have not been on the boards much, and am wondering if depression, anxiety and feelings similar to "chemo brain" have happened to anyone else. I see above where someone mentioned they are a mess - that is how I am. Completely discombobulated. I did fantastic through 6 months of chemo, was a warrior for the BMX, and now I am trashed. ANy thoughts, advice?? Thanks! Hugs! (Love the cat story! My daughter just brought her 9 y.o. cat to vet today as she lost a lot of weight in a week, they are checking thyroid and checking for diabetes. We had to laugh - DD is an RN and may have to give her cat insulin shots! My DS has Type1 so we are all too familiar with insulin injections!)
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: May 6, 2011 09:12PM momof2greatkids wrote: i worked through it - went before work each day - lucky though that rads were 5 min from  home, and work 5-10 minutes from there. If I had to commute the way I did when I lived in Californi, I do not think I could have done it every single day. I was fine the first few weeks, then it can start to exhaust you. About when they were done I was beyond exhausted, and am just starting (I think it has been 4-6 weeks since I finished) to feel some energy returning. We are all different with so many other factors to account for - commute, children, etc. Good luck with your decision! (one thing I may hve done different would be to schedule them for the end of the day - I didn't do that because in my job it is near impossible to actully leave on time for n appt (partly my fault cause I can't say no when someone has something they say is important to get done) but at least then I could have gone right home after. Just a thought! (and sorry, the "a' key is only working part time on  my keyboard!
Posts.Title: Working Through Radiation? Katarina pat01

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 11:02PM momof2greatkids wrote: I am here too! Half way through rads, 8 months of herceptin to go, and lymphedema. The lymphedema is worse than anything so far. Chemo - doable (TCH), rads - creepy but doable (and the fatigue - ugh!), port is now my friend, double mastectomy - totally doable. But I hate LE - it is not so doable!
Posts.Title: Any Stage 3, HER2+ (only), Node(s) + Girls here? Frankie_ amlg1

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 11:45PM momof2greatkids wrote: Hi 3 beans, according to my onc, MRI's for dense breasts are a great dx tool. I hope they order one for you, better to see what the heck is going on now! And your appt will be here before you know it, luckily it is not months out as so many other women here have posted they have to wait.  agh - i have chemo brain - reason i was posting was to say how we women always let ourselves be psyched into thinking "it is in our heads." It really makes me mad. BC can hurt, and so can benign tumors/cysts. I had pain in the breast area and shooting pain from the lump site to my underarm (where more cancer was found.) This DOES NOT mean yours is cancer, it is just to dispel the myth that cancerous tumors "do not hurt"  - bull! They do. AGAIN, so do non-cancerous, but my chemo-brain point was that the pain is not imaginary, and i am tired of people's sexist attitude that it is "all in our heads." Take care, try and "chill" until your appointment!!!
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: May 6, 2011 05:09PM momof2greatkids wrote: ((hugs)) from me too Katie. Am so sorry. It is good that you are her2+, the Herceptin can kick butt on tumors, and I hope you can get the Herceptin ASAP.
Posts.Title: Does this sound like BC? katie31 GoldenEyes

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 12:46PM momof2greatkids wrote: Hi Ellen - i had the same thing during chemo - it was awful! Came on fast, was very painful to walk, soles of feet were bright red, and yes it went to my hands. I think they did call it Hand/Foot syndrome, but they said it was from the chemo. It took several weeks to go away, and did not come back - thankfully! I am sorry I cannot remember what I did to ease the pain! Hoping you feel better!
Posts.Title: Hand-Foot Syndrome or similar SE? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 05:50AM momof2greatkids wrote: Hi Wherria - I don't post too often but am on the site for a couple of hours every night soaking up info. I am 3 weeks post chemo (started in August) and I feel the same way - leg aches, walking up the stairs out of breath, and my collar bone really hurts. Since my BMX is scheduled for a week from Monday, I am trying to get a lot of things done (cleaning, painting the kitchen, making sure I have everything) and am starting to freak out at how will get it all done. I started a zillion projects I want to finish as I am so afraid of possible limited use of arms after surgery! I think I am doing it to keep my mind off of the upcoming surgery and I have another PET scan tomorrow. The BMX recovery completely freaks me out. (Not so much the thought that I am losing my breasts, which is a bummer, but how am I going to heal, do things etc. My daughter will only be here for 4 days then it is just me!) Anhow, sorry to go on about myself, I am just getting so nervous. I just wanted to let you know physically I am not as strong as I thought I would be after last chemo. God Bless! Oh yeah - what caught my eye too was you live in Winfield! I used to, and my children were born there! Great town!!
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 11:42PM momof2greatkids wrote: pejkug3 - TCH through arm w/ nodes removed? Not by my onc. SuperSally - I HATED my port for at least 3 weeks, now 8 months later it is still my best friend! I LOVE it. So just in case you decide to get it, don't get too upset if you hate it at first, you will grow to at least like it!
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 07:41PM momof2greatkids wrote: BMX a breeze - i felt like a giant load was off my chest!  hahaha! I really did - I was strangely filled with joy just knowing the stress of constant surveillance was over! I did not need any painkillers, I was prepared for horrible pain etc. as it seems like such a major surgery, but it really was fine. I did 6 rounds TCH, finished 29 rads/5 boosts today (yippee!) and am exhausted, but okay! 1 yr of herceptin still to go. In retrospect, there are things I should have been told between surg and rads re physical therapy, and you should try and get that info now so you can start slowly to get your arms ready for radiation. I think you'll do great, and as with chemo, rads will seem like they will never be over - then poof - done!!!
Posts.Title: Which is harder...chemo or bilateral mastectomy? 1awesomemom BMac

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 07:49PM momof2greatkids wrote: meme31 - YOU NEED TO GET A BIOPSY. WHen i read that you have our notorious "dense" breasts, you cannot rely on ANY scan to detect it - PLEEEEEASE find a way to get a biopsy. I have dense breasts and was NEVER EVER told that certain BC's (of course the bad ones) are NOT detected on mammo's in dense breasts. Had i been armed with this knowledge, I would not have allowed them to zap me with mammos for the past 10 years. What a waste of resources! And i had the money to do ultrasounds if insurance would not have covered it - but i had no idea.   What area do you live in? I am sure if you post it (the general area) one of us on this wonderful site will know of resources in your area than can help you get a biopsy. Please, for your children's sake, keep pushing them to biopsy you!! In the interim, take it easy, show your children joy, etc. etc. ! The test may very well come back fine, but you need to know!
Posts.Title: 31 and mamo was negative but i have a lump meme31 kira1234

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 11:25PM momof2greatkids wrote: Socks -  please get a second opinion for your Mom! Your posts made me log in-which I rarely do. First, please understand that chemo is usually not as horrible or terrifying as it sounds, and kind of like childbirth, even a few months after it is hard to remember how bad it was because it is totally worth it - the chance to beat this booger. I guess from all I researched, learned and experienced throughout this, I am shocked they are not considering chemo, and chemo NOW. There has to be some info missing or results that give it a lower stage or something. Please, please get a second opinion, if only so you do not have to question yourself later should (God forbid) things get worse, which is a valid concern you have mentioned. God Bless you and your family.
Posts.Title: Stage III but they say no chemo? Good news, but is it accurate? Pinkfuzzysocks34 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 07:10PM momof2greatkids wrote: OMgoodness - made it through the bmx surgery, am about 9 hours out of surgery!!!!!!!! what a crazy (good and bad)  week last week, didn't post this - monday had pet scan after 6 doses Herceptin, Taxeotare, Carboplatin, to see if stupid cancer had spread,  dr. result appt on thurs. Tuesday found out someone at dr's office messed up and did not get approvel for other breast. i freaked  out, told them i am NOT doing this twice etc. Wonderful lady at work helped me "rattle enough cages" that ins co said the would have an answer on thurs.  I also have a manual 4sp older car without power steering that i will not be able to drive for the forseeable future (BMX, RADS, RECON ETc.. SO, THIS IS how last THursdaywent:   9 a.m. at work, rcv phone all from surgeons office, bmx a go!!!   1120 am, 2 professors at work that were buying a new car gave me their beautiful used auto trans car that is 4wd! I am so grateful and tickled! Then another prof said better get a trifecta and get good scan results, and I did!!!!! What a day that was!!!! So FF to today's bmx and I am a bit upset re the whole lymph node subject.  part of why i consented to neoadjunct chemo was to save as many  lymph nodes as possible.  I was told the chemo may "clear" some of the nodes. I am falling asleep will finish post later. thanks to all for your well wishes, it meant so much to me! Biker - so far totally doable, will be thinking of you in the a.m.
